block.p: Mel Gussow's ''nary a nibble in the kitchen of 'Miss Julie' '' [ ''The Curtain Rises on Kelp Lasagna and Chopped Liver,'' Feb. 26 ] is language worthy of Oscar Wilde but, unfortunately, inaccurate. Strindberg uses food quite deliberately during the first scene in ''Miss Julie'' to establish relationships and to reveal personalities.

Kristin, the cook, prepares a meal for Jean, the valet, which he hopes is ''tasty.'' The food is, she says in the Sprigge translation, ''just a little bit of kidney I cut off their joint.'' Jean allows as kidney is his ''special delice,'' but chastises her for not warming the plate. Kristin then offers Jean a beer, which he refuses for ''something better than that'' as he produces a bottle of wine which he has taken from the Count's cellar; he proceeds to instruct her on its label and value.

Thus, in a short conversation about food and drink, Strindberg has revealed a sensual, class-conscious valet and a pilfering cook. Later, Jean uses the bottle of wine to humiliate the fallen Miss Julie, who prefers beer, as she recognizes herself as an accomplice to a petty thief. Strindberg's Naturalism would dictate food on the play's kitchen table. J. C. KOHL Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

Mel Gussow replies: Rechecking the Strindbergian menu, one is surprised to discover not only nibbles in the kitchen of ''Miss Julie'' but also hot chocolate in ''The Stronger'' and a steady flow of food and wine in other cafes and creameries visited in the works of the august playwright. The captain in ''Dance of Death,'' a confirmed epicurean, drinks grog and smacks his lips over remembered veal. In the case of Strindberg, there is a healthy appetite in a wintry climate.
